answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
There are a few communities who have used "managed competition" to benchmark against private sector/outsourcing.  Carrollton, TX has done this for about a decade and is always the first that comes to mind - they even have a "director of competition" position. Having city staff bid against contractors keeps both sides competitive in the long run, and prevents it going completely to either public or private keeping service delivery high and lowering costs.

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
Like everything, there are pro's and con's.  There area number of cities over the years that have privatized the utilities.  Not an uncommon practice to give you a great deal going in and then over time the price goes up and up.  At this point you have sold all your equipment and removed the staff so it would costs a fortune to get back into the game.  Nonetheless, many have purchased back the operation and resumed government Gethsemane of the asset.  Remember, the number one costs difference is to salary, its benefits, so you may address the costs by controlling the benefits.

answers.author: Pamela Muse
answers.text:
David – I hope the following is helpful:
A recent Wall Street Journal article reports on (http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704216804575423633799731128.html) what seems to be an accelerating trend: cities privatizing their water supplies. According to the article, the Indianapolis city-county council voted last month to sell its water and sewer utilities to a charitable trust; San Jose and Pittsburgh are considering selling their water systems as well, while Sacramento is now allowing Nestle, SA to bottle and sell “excess” tap water.

author: David Dillner
text:
The City's Water Utility has been financially strained for several years and will remain so based on what we are projecting out into the future. I am in the process of developing a plan of action to address the situation, and feel that all options should be on the table for discussion. 
One option that has not been presented yet is privatizing water and sewer utilities. I don't know yet if this is a feasible option that would address the issues, but would like to hear what others have learned in either exploring the idea or implementing a privatized solution.
Questions I currently have are:  1) what was the process used to make the decision, select the private contractor, and implement the deal? 2) What  parts of the process would you do differently and what was very successful? 3) Did you hire a consultant to assist in assess the feasibility of privatization? 4) How did you select a consultant and/or the eventual contractor? 5) What were the major political concerns and how were they addressed? 6) Are you satisfied with the services?
title: Privatizing Water/Sewer Utilities
